questions.question: What is the primary difference between axial and helical CT scanning?

options.A: Axial CT uses contrast agents, while helical CT does not.
options.B: Axial CT scans in single slices, while helical CT scans continuously in a spiral.
options.C: Helical CT requires more radiation than axial CT.
options.D: Axial CT produces 3D images, while helical CT produces 2D images.

questions.explanation: continuously collects data in a spiral path as the patient moves through the scanner. Axial and Helical CT: Axial CT (Computed Tomography) and Helical CT(also known as Spiral CT) are two different scanning techniques used in medical imaging to obtain cross-sectional images of the body. Axial CT Helical CT Definition Axial CT scans acquire images in discrete slices or cross-sections of the body. The scanner rotates around the patient, capturing one slice at a time. Helical CT scans acquire images continuously in a spiral pattern as the patient moves through the scanner. This allows for a continuous data stream and overlapping slices. Data Acquisition The table holding the patient moves in small increments between scans. After each slice is acquired, the table stops to allow for the next slice to be taken. The scanner rotates around the patient while the table moves through the gantry simultaneously, resulting in a spiral path of data collection. Scan Time Generally longer due to the stepwise approach, as the table must move and stop for each slice. Much faster than axial CT, as the entire area can be scanned in a single breath-hold, which is beneficial for patients who may have difficulty remaining still. Image Quality Typically provides high-resolution images, making it ideal for detailed examinations, especially of the brain and other structures. Provides good quality images and can be processed for 3D reconstructions , making it useful for dynamic studies and quick imaging. Advantages High-resolution images, ideal for detailed examinations. Faster scans, less motion artifact, and the ability to reconstruct images in multiple planes. Disadvantages Longer scan times and may be less effective for dynamic imaging. May require higher radiation doses depending on parameters and can have slightly lower image resolution compared to axial scans. Axial CT uses contrast agents, while helical CT does not.(Option A): Both axial and helical CT can use contrast agents, depending on the clinical requirements. Helical CT requires more radiation than axial CT.(Option C): Helical CT does not inherently require more radiation than axial CT; radiation exposure can depend on various factors, including scan parameters. Axial CT produces 3D images, while helical CT produces 2D images.(Option D): Both axial and helical CT can be processed to create 3D images. Reference: David Sutton Textbook of Radiology edition 8, page 254, 255, 256 & 257

questions.question: A 38 year old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain and menorrhagia due to multiple uterine fibroids. She is exploring non-invasive treatment options and wishes to avoid surgery. Her gynecologist suggests high-intensity focused ultrasound (HIFU) as a potential treatment. What is the primary mechanism by which HIFU treats uterine fibroids? the fibroid. ischemia.

options.A: HIFU emits continuous low-energy ultrasound waves that dissolve fibroid tissue through vibration.
options.B: HIFU directs focused ultrasound energy to induce thermal damage and coagulation necrosis within
options.C: HIFU causes cavitation within blood vessels, disrupting the fibroid’s blood supply and leading to
options.D: HIFU uses ultrasound energy to fragment fibroid tissue through mechanical shearing forces.

questions.explanation: coagulation necrosis within the fibroid. the fibroid. Therapeutic applications of USG- High-intensity focused ultrasonography (HIFU) Mechanism (Option B) Uses high-intensity ultrasound waves focused on a specific target area, delivering localized energy while minimizing damage to surrounding tissues. Thermal Effects: Heat from ultrasound energy leads to coagulation necrosis. Cavitation Effects: Formation and collapse of microbubbles generate mechanical forces for tissue destruction. Applications Bleeding Sites: Coagulates vessels to stop bleeding. Uterine Fibroids: Induces necrosis in fibroid tissue, causing shrinkage. Tumours: Destroys tumour cells in organs like the prostate, liver and breast while sparing healthy tissues. Limitations Gas or Bone Interference: Ultrasound waves can be scattered or reflected by gas or bone, reducing effectiveness. Unintended Tissue Damage: Heating and damage can occur to normal tissue, especially near reflectors like bowel gas or bone. Guidance Systems Ultrasound Guidance: Real-time imaging for accurate targeting. MRI Guidance: Monitors tissue temperature during treatment, allowing better control of thermal effects. Reference: David Sutton textbook of Radiology & Imaging Edition 8, Volume I, Page 231,232

questions.question: A 62 year old woman with a history of hepatic metastases undergoes an ultrasound study using contrast-enhanced ultrasonography (CEUS) for liver lesion characterization. CEUS employs microbubbles that improve imaging of small vessels and capillaries. Which of the following is a primary advantage of CEUS compared to traditional contrast-enhanced CT or MRI?

options.A: CEUS allows targeted drug delivery in specific lesions
options.B: CEUS allows real-time imaging with enhanced lesion detection
options.C: CEUS is a safe alternative for patients with renal impairment

questions.explanation: gadolinium), CEUS uses microbubbles that are well-tolerated and not nephrotoxic. This makes it an excellent choice for patients with renal impairment who need detailed imaging. Contrast-Enhanced Ultrasonography (CEUS) Basic Principle Uses microbubbles (3-5 µm) as contrast agents Microbubbles contain gases (air, nitrogen, perfluorocarbons) which are encapsulated in albumin or phospholipid shells Mechanism Microbubbles create acoustic impedance mismatch ↓ Generate nonlinear harmonic frequencies ↓ Enables visualization of small vessels/capillaries Uses Liver lesion characterization Intervention guidance Treatment response monitoring Vascular flow assessment Non-vascular uses (e.g., tubal patency) Advantages / Limitations Advantages Enhanced lesion detection Potential for targeted drug delivery Safe alternative to CT/MRI contrast Enables non-invasive pressure measurements CEUS allows targeted drug delivery in specific lesions (Option A): CEUS has applications in targeted drug delivery, but its not primary advantage over traditional contrast-enhanced CT or MRI. CEUS allows real-time imaging with enhanced lesion detection (Option B): One of the main advantages of CEUS is that it provides real-time imaging with enhanced visualization of small vessels and capillaries, aiding in liver lesion characterization. But this is not the primary advantage over traditional contrast-enhanced CT or MRI. Reference: David Sutton textbook of Radiology & Imaging Edition 8, Volume I, Page 223, 229, 230

questions.question: A 45 year old woman presents to the emergency department with dull abdominal pain. An ultrasound of the abdomen is performed, and a cystic structure is seen in the right kidney. The ultrasound technician notes increased echogenicity behind the cystic structure. Which of the following best explains this ultrasound finding?

options.A: Posterior Acoustic shadowing
options.B: Posterior acoustic enhancement

questions.explanation: fluid-filled structure (like a cyst), causing less attenuation (energy loss) compared to surrounding tissue. As a result, tissues behind the fluid appear brighter, which explains the increased echogenicity behind the cystic structure. Black and white principles of USG Posterior Acoustic Enhancement Ultrasound artifact where tissues behind fluid appear brighter Occurs because fluid causes less attenuation of ultrasound waves Mechanism: Ultrasound beam encounters fluid-filled structure ↓ Less energy lost passing through fluid vs. surrounding tissue ↓ More energy reaches tissues behind fluid ↓ Result: Increased echogenicity (brightness) posterior to fluid Helpful For Identifying: Cysts Bladder Ascites Other fluid-filled structures Can cause misinterpretation: Example: Kidneys viewed through ascites may appear falsely hyperechoic Posterior Acoustic shadowing (Option A ruled out) Ultrasound artifact appearing as dark area behind highly attenuating structures Results from significant reduction in ultrasound intensity Mechanism: Ultrasound beam hits highly reflective/attenuating structure ↓ Most sound waves are blocked or reflected ↓ Little to no energy reaches tissues behind structure ↓ Result: Dark (hypoechoic) area appears on image Helpful For Identifying: Calcifications Stones Foreign bodies Bone Reverberation artifact (Option C): Reverberation occurs when ultrasound waves bounce back and forth between two strong reflectors, creating multiple lines on the image. This artifact does not relate to the increased brightness seen here. Comet tail artifact (Option D): A form of reverberation artifact, comet tail appears as a series of closely spaced echoes behind a reflective object, not related to increased brightness behind a fluid-filled structure

questions.question: A 45 year old female patient presents for a carotid Doppler ultrasound due to complaints of transient ischemic attacks. During the examination, the radiologist notices that the displayed velocity of blood flow in the carotid artery appears higher than expected. Upon reviewing the images, he suspects an artifact affecting the velocity measurements. Which artifact is most likely responsible for the incorrect velocity display, and what is the best method to mitigate it?

options.A: Aliasing; mitigate by increasing the pulse repetition frequency (PRF).
options.B: Blooming; mitigate by increasing the wall filter settings.
options.C: Direction Ambiguity; mitigate by adjusting the beam angle to be more parallel to the flow.
options.D: Twinkle Artifact; mitigate by adjusting the color gain settings.

questions.explanation: high blood flow velocities are being measured, such as in the carotid arteries . It occurs when the velocity of blood flow exceeds the Nyquist limit (which is half the PRF), causing the displayed waveform to wrap around , leading to overestimation or misinterpretation of velocity. Aliasing appears as a sudden shift or wrap-around of the spectral waveform or color scale reversal (e.g., red to blue). To mitigate aliasing: Increase PRF (not decrease). Use a lower frequency transducer . Adjust the baseline downward . Use continuous wave Doppler if feasible. So, the mitigation option in the question is incorrect — you should increase PRF, not decrease it. Corrected Answer: Aliasing; mitigate by increasing the pulse repetition frequency (PRF). Ruling Out Incorrect Options: Blooming (Option B): Incorrect , because blooming causes overestimation of vessel diameter or area due to excessive gain; it doesn’t affect velocity. Increasing wall filter doesn't mitigate blooming. Direction Ambiguity (Option C): Incorrect , this occurs with transcranial or abdominal Doppler using large sample volumes ; not typical in carotid studies . Twinkle Artifact (Option D): Incorrect , seen in color Doppler near calcifications or stones , not relevant to velocity overestimation in carotids. Summary Table: Artifact Appearance Best Solution Aliasing Wrap-around waveform or reversed color Increase PRF , lower frequency, shift baseline Blooming Overfilled color/velocity extending beyond vessel wall Reduce gain, optimize wall filters Direction Ambiguity Flow appears in both directions Use angle correction, reduce sample volume Twinkle Artifact Color speckling behind calcified area Lower color gain or change angle Reference: David Sutton textbook of Radiology & Imaging Edition 8, Volume I, Page 209-221

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath following a traumatic injury. M-mode ultrasound is utilized to assess pneumothorax. Which specific ultrasound finding would indicate the absence of a pneumothorax?

options.A: Absence of pleural sliding
options.B: Barcode sign (stratosphere sign)

questions.explanation: The presence of this pattern confirms that there is no pneumothorax. "Barcode sign" or "stratosphere sign" is indicative of a pneumothorax, where the normal pleural sliding is absent , and the image resembles parallel horizontal lines (Option A and B ruled out). M-mode Ultrasound M-mode (Motion mode) uses a rapid sequence of B-mode scans to track organ movement relative to the probe. It captures motion over time, providing clinicians with a dynamic view of structure movements, which is crucial for assessing processes that static 2D ultrasound cannot. Clinical Applications Pneumothorax : Detects air in the pleural space by visualizing pleural movement. Left Ventricular Function : Assesses heart performance via measurements like E-point septal separation. Cardiac Tamponade : Detects fluid around the heart. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy : Evaluates abnormal thickening of the heart muscle. Diaphragmatic Kinetics : Reliable for measuring diaphragmatic movement, both at rest and during forced breathing. Echocardiography : Measures heart function through mitral (MAPSE) and tricuspid (TAPSE) annular plane systolic excursions. Volume Status: Evaluates fluid status via inferior and superior vena cava diameters. Identifies issues like systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve and cardiac tamponade. Advantages High temporal resolution, offering precise timing of motion. Quick and easy to perform, even for less experienced users. Applicable across various clinical settings. Absence of diaphragmatic movement (Option C): This is related to diaphragmatic paralysis or dysfunction, not pneumothorax, and is not a reliable indicator in this context.

Infection Control Cover transducer and skin with plastic for patients with open wounds or skin issues. ↓ Apply gel on both sides of the plastic. ↓ Clean transducer after each use Principle of USG : Ultrasound operates on the pulse-echo principle, utilizing piezoelectric materials found in the ultrasound probe's crystal. questions.question: In which scenario would CECT be preferred over NCCT?

options.A: Evaluating a fracture in a long bone
options.B: Assessing a lung nodule for malignancy

questions.explanation: nodule and its characteristics, which helps in differentiating between benign and malignant lesions. It also allows for better assessment of surrounding structures and lymph nodes. Non-Contrast Computed Tomography (NCCT) and Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) Non-Contrast Computed Tomography (NCCT) Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) NCCT refers to CT imaging performed without the use of intravenous contrast agents. CECT involves the administration of an intravenous contrast agent to enhance the visibility of vascular structures and improve differentiation of tissues in the body. Indications : Bone Injuries: Fractures, especially of the spine and long bones. (Option A ruled out) Kidney Stones: Evaluation of renal calculi (stones) and urinary tract obstruction. (Option C ruled out) Head Trauma: Detecting hemorrhage or skull fractures. (Option D ruled out) Acute Abdomen: Initial evaluation of acute abdominal pain (appendicitis, diverticulitis). Indications: Tumor Detection: Identifying and characterizing masses or tumors in various organs. Pulmonary Diseases: Assessing lung pathology (pneumonia, lung nodules). (Option B) Vascular Assessment: Evaluating blood vessels for stenosis, thrombosis, or aneurysms. Infection : Assessing abscesses or inflammatory conditions where contrast can delineate structures. Staging of Cancer: Determining the extent of malignancies by evaluating lymph nodes and distant metastases. Assessment of Organ Perfusion : Evaluating blood flow in organs. Advantages : No Allergic Reactions: Eliminates the risk of allergic reactions to contrast agents. No Need for Renal Function Assessment: Suitable for patients with renal impairment who cannot tolerate contrast. Faster : Typically quicker to perform than CECT, as no time is needed for contrast administration. Cost-effective: Generally less expensive than CECT. Advantages: Enhanced Visualization : Improves the contrast between different tissues, making it easier to identify abnormalities. Better Soft Tissue Detail: Provides superior detail of soft tissue structures compared to NCCT. Vascular Imaging: Excellent for visualizing blood vessels and detecting vascular pathologies. Limitations: Limited Diagnostic Capability: May not provide enough detail for soft tissue structures or vascular assessments. Less Sensitivity: Lower sensitivity for detecting certain conditions, such as tumors or vascular abnormalities, compared to CECT. Limitations: Risk of Allergic Reactions: Possible allergic reactions to contrast agents, ranging from mild to severe (anaphylaxis). Renal Impairment: Requires caution in patients with pre-existing kidney disease, as contrast can further compromise renal function (risk of Contrast-Induced Nephropathy). Increased Radiation Exposure: Slightly higher radiation exposure compared to NCCT due to additional imaging phases.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male patient presents with a 6-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a dry cough. He is a former smoker, having quit 10 years ago, and has no significant past medical history. On examination, he has clubbing of the fingers and fine crackles on lung auscultation. Pulmonary function tests reveal a restrictive pattern with reduced lung volumes and a decreased diffusion capacity.Which imaging modality is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis of this condition?

options.A: Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) of the chest
options.B: High-Resolution CT (HRCT) of the chest

questions.explanation: (shortness of breath) Dry cough Clubbing of fingers Fine crackles on auscultation Restrictive lung pattern on pulmonary function tests HRCT is the gold standard for diagnosing IPF , as it can reveal the characteristic patterns of fibrosis, such as reticular patterns, honeycombing, and ground-glass opacities. HRCT showing IPF High-Resolution CT (HRCT): Definition Specialized imaging technique that provides highly detailed cross-sectional images of the body's internal structures, primarily the lungs Technique Thin Collimation: Uses thin slices (usually 1 mm or less) to improve image resolution. High Spatial Resolution: Optimized scanning protocols to enhance the detail of structures. Breath-Holding: Images are often obtained during full inspiration to reduce motion artifacts. Indications Pulmonary Assessment: Primarily used to evaluate lung diseases, especially interstitial lung diseases (e.g., Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis, sarcoidosis). Tumor Evaluation: Assessing lung nodules and tumors. (For Pancoast tumor MRI is preferred) Infectious Diseases : Identifying lung infections (pneumonia, tuberculosis). Key Imaging Features Reticular Patterns: Suggestive of fibrosis and interstitial lung disease. Ground-Glass Opacities: Indicate inflammation or partial consolidation. Nodules and Masses: Detailed visualization of pulmonary nodules. Advantages High Sensitivity and Specificity: Superior ability to detect and characterize lung pathologies compared to standard CT or X-rays. Detailed Assessment: Provides detailed anatomical information, aiding in accurate diagnosis and treatment planning. 3D Reconstruction: Data can be processed to create 3D images for better anatomical visualization. Limitations Radiation Exposure: Increased radiation dose compared to conventional radiography. Cost : Generally more expensive than standard imaging modalities. Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) of the chest (Option A): It is not the preferred method for diagnosing IPF as it does not provide the high-resolution images necessary to visualize the specific interstitial patterns of fibrosis. MRI of the chest (Option C): Not routinely used for the diagnosis of IPF; HRCT is preferred due to better visualization of lung parenchyma. Ultrasound of the chest (Option D): Not a suitable modality for diagnosing interstitial lung diseases like IPF, as it cannot provide detailed images of lung parenchyma.

questions.question: Which window setting would be most appropriate for viewing bone structures in a CT scan?

options.A: Low window level and narrow window width
options.B: High window level and wide window width
options.C: Low window level and wide window width
options.D: High window level and narrow window width

questions.explanation: because it allows for better differentiation of highly dense tissues. In CT imaging, the window refers to the range of Hounsfield units (HU) that are displayed on the CT image , allowing radiologists to better visualize specific tissues or structures by adjusting the image contrast. The window settings include two key components: Window Width (WW) : This defines the range of Hounsfield units that will be displayed. It controls the contrast of the image. A narrow window width is used for better contrast of soft tissues. A wide window width is used for imaging high-contrast structures like bone . Window Level (WL): This determines the central Hounsfield value of the window range and adjusts the brightness of the image. A higher window level is used to visualize dense tissues like bones . A lower window level is used for soft tissues. Types of CT Windows: Bone window: High window level and wide window width to clearly view bones and other dense structures. Lung window: Narrow window width and lower window level for optimal visualization of lung parenchyma and air spaces. Soft tissue window: Lower window level and narrower width to focus on soft tissue structures like muscles, organs, and the brain. Low window level and narrow window width (Option A): are more suitable for soft tissues where contrast needs to be enhanced, not for dense structures like bone. Low window level and wide window width (Option C): would reduce brightness, making it harder to see dense structures like bones. High window level and narrow window width (Option D): While a high window level is appropriate for bones, a narrow window width would reduce the ability to distinguish different densities within the bone itself. Reference: Ct window

questions.explanation: X-ray: Introduction Discovered by W.C. Roentgen on 8 November 1895 (International Day of Radiology). Production By sudden deceleration of fast-moving electron beam (Option A) Working principle The Cathode (filament) is an electron source that produces the electron beam and the Anode is a tungsten target for the electron beam. The electron beam travels from the cathode (negatively charged) to the anode (positively charged) (Option D) Thermionic emission occurs at the Cathode. Blocking of the electron beam is done at the Anode, where 99% of heat dissipation is by Radiation (Option C) and the remaining 1% escapes through the window onto a film called X-rays. Components The Cathode Made up of Tungsten (atomic no.- 74) & Thorium . The Anode Made up of Tungsten & Rhenium (Option B) . Rotatory anodes are preferred (to avoid focal points), now stationary anodes are only used in Portable X-ray machines. Glass envelope Made up of Lead (Pb). Focusing cup Made up of Nickel. Bremsstrahlung radiation (produced by the interaction of electron with nucleus) : Electromagnetic radiation produced by the deceleration of a charged particle when deflected by another charged particle. When an electron beam (negatively charged) travels towards the anode, the nucleus (positively charged) gets deflected and travels in a different direction. Bremsstrahlung radiation depends upon the angle of deflection . Characteristic radiation:

questions.explanation: tomography), IVP (Intravenous pyelography). Non-ionizing radiation: MRI, USG-Doppler. Ionizing and non-ionizing radiation: Ionizing radiation Non-ionizing radiation Rays that have the ability to displace orbiting electrons from the atom thus causing biomolecular damage. Some electromagnetic and mechanical waves do not dissipate energy and hence are called non-ionizing. Conventional X-rays , Mammography, CT Contrast X-rays: HSG, IVP, ERCP, Myelography Nuclear imaging (gamma rays): PET, SPECT, Scintigraphy UV rays USG (including Doppler, FAST) MRI (Magnetic resonance imaging), MRCP Thermography Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/ionizing-radiation-1
